abstract.text: L, Molecular characterization of SARS-CoV-2 in the first COVID-19 cluster in France reveals an amino-acid deletion in nsp2 (Asp268Del), Clinical Microbiology and Infection, https://doi.

body_text.text: 1 Molecular characterization of SARS-CoV-2 in the first COVID-19 cluster in 1 France reveals an amino-acid deletion in nsp2 (Asp268Del) 2 Antonin Bal 1,2,3,4 ‡, Grégory Destras 1,2,3 ‡, Alexandre Gaymard 1,2,3 , Maude Bouscambert-3
Duchamp 1,2, , Martine Valette 1,2 , Vanessa Escuret 1,2,3 , Emilie Frobert 1,2,3 , Geneviève 4
Billaud 1,2 , Sophie Trouillet-Assant 3,4 , Valérie Cheynet 4 , Karen Brengel-Pesce 4 , Florence 5

Morfin 1,2,3 , Bruno Lina 1,2,3 , Laurence Josset 1,2,3 6 The whole genome sequence (WGS) generated from sample #2 was deposited on GISAID 48 (EPI_ISL_410486). The phylogenetic analysis using the 571 WGS of SARS-CoV-2 publicly 49 available (as of March 17 th 2020) found that this sequence clustered with a sequence 50 (EPI_ISL_408488) collected in Jiangsu, China on January 19 th , suggesting a separate 51 introduction of the virus from Asia (Fig 1) . Compared to the reference SARS-CoV-2 52 sequence, a 3-nucleotide deletion in open reading frame 1ab (ORF1ab) at position 1607-1609 53 was identified. This deletion was found in 100% of the reads at this position with a coverage 54 of 1745X around the deletion. Importantly, this deletion was also identified in 100% of the 55 reads of sample #1 and sample #3 with a coverage of 54X and 481X, respectively. Using 56

CoV-GLUE resource, we found that this mutation leads to a deletion of amino acid 268 in 57 non-structural protein 2 (nsp2) [5] . This deletion in nsp2 (Asp268Del) was also characterized 58 in 37/571 (6.1%) of the WGS available on March 17 th (England n = 6; Netherlands n = 31). 59 WGS-based phylogenetic analysis found that 15 viruses containing this specific deletion were 60 close to viruses collected in China between December 2019 and early February 2020, while 61 23 viruses collected in the Netherlands in March 2020 have slightly diverged (Fig 1) . 62 SARS-CoV2 sequences were not further compared between the 2 patients due to largely 63 incomplete coverage of SARS-CoV2 genome in sample #1. Nonetheless, the longitudinal 64 samples from the asymptomatic patient (sample #2 vs sample #3) were compared using a 65 minimum depth of coverage of 100X in order to make a preliminary assessment of intra-host 66 genetic variability. Three SNVs were noticed between the 2 samples: C366A (nsp1: S34Y), 67 A20475G (synonymous mutation in nsp15), T24084A (protein S: L841H), suggesting intra-68 host evolution of the virus. For all 3 positions, nucleotides from sample #2 were still detected 69 in sample #3, but as minor variants. 70
In this short report, we present the first genetic characterization of a COVID-19 cluster in 71

Europe. Despite low viral loads, the mNGS workflow used herein allowed to characterize the 72 4 whole genome sequences of SARS-CoV2 isolated from an asymptomatic patient, in 2 clinical 73 samples collected 1 day apart. Comparison of these sequences suggests viral evolution with 74 development of quasispecies. Specific studies using high depth of coverage to assess 75 quasispecies are needed to characterize potential intra-host adaptation. In addition, the present 76 workflow identified a new deletion in nsp2 (Asp268Del) The analysis included 571 WGS of SARS-CoV2 (>29,000 bp) collected in humans and 84 available on GISAID from March 17 th , 2020. The following sequences were excluded from 85 the analysis: EPI_ISL_406592, EPI_ISL_414588, EPI_ISL_412900, EPI_ISL_408487, 86 EPI_ISL_408483 and EPI_ISL_406595 because they were outliers, and EPI_ISL_413747, 87
The 88 hCoV19/Wuhan/IPBCAMSWH01/2019 strain was used as an outgroup virus. Genetic 89 distances were calculated using the Kimura's 2-parameter model (K80) and pairwise deletion. 90

The tree was constructed by the neighbour-joining method using R seqinr and ggtree 91 packages and validated using 1000 bootstrap pseudo-replicates. Sequence from sample #2 92 (EPI_ISL_410486) is indicated by the black arrow. Nucleotide alignment (1600 to 1614) is 93 depicted as a heatmap on the right panel with the 3-nucleotide deletion shown in black. 94

FIGREF0.text: which was found in all 3 samples 77 originating from this cluster. The analysis of 571 WGS identified this deletion in 37 other 78 viruses collected in England (February) and in Netherlands (March), suggesting the spread of 79 this deletion in Europe. The impact of Asp268Del on SARS-CoV-2 transmission and 80 pathogenicity, as well as on PCR performances and anti-viral strategy should be rapidly 81 evaluated in further studies. WGS-based phylogenetic analysis of SARS-CoV-2 83

TABREF0.text: Lyon Sud, Pierre-Bénite, France 13 ‡These authors have contributed equally to this work 14 Corresponding author: Laurence Josset, Pharm.D, Ph.D 15 In December 2019, a novel coronavirus emerged in China, causing outbreaks of unexplained 24 pneumonia [1]. The virus was subsequently identified as a beta-coronavirus and named severe 25 acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). SARS-CoV-2 is responsible of the 26 coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic which includes asymptomatic, upper, and 27 lower respiratory tract infections. Among the first European cases of COVID-19, 6 were 28 associated with a cluster of transmission in the French Alps in late January 2020 [2]. The 29 index case of this cluster travelled from Singapore to France and went back to the United 30 Kingdom (UK) where he was tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 on February 6 th . Here, we 31 aimed to investigate the French cases related to this cluster using metagenomic next-32 generation sequencing (mNGS) analysis. 33 Of the 6 contact patients tested positive for SARS-CoV2, the 3 samples with highest viral 34 loads (assessed by RT-PCR targeting the RdRp gene) were selected for mNGS [3]. One 35 nasopharyngeal swab was collected from a patient with an upper respiratory tract infection on 36February 7 th (sample #1, Ct = 31.3). The other two samples were collected from the same 37 asymptomatic patient on February 8 th (sample #2, nasopharyngeal swab, Ct = 31.1) and 9 th 38 (sample #3, nasopharyngeal aspirate, Ct = 28.8). 39 A previously described mNGS protocol was used but for which DNase treatment was 40 performed after nucleic acid extraction in order to increase sensitivity of RNA viruses' 41 detection[4]. Low quality and human reads were filtered out and remaining reads were 42 aligned to the SARS-CoV-2 reference genome (isolate Wuhan-Hu-1, EPI_ISL_402125) using 43 BWA-MEM algorithm. A mean of 19 445 767 reads per sample were generated, of which a 44 mean of 605 243 reads per sample were mapped to the SARS-CoV-2 reference genome. 45Percentage of genome covered at a minimum depth of coverage of 100X was 38.3% for 46 sample #1, 99.6% for sample #2 and 80.6% for sample #3.

Investigations complied with the General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 114 2016/679 and Directive 95/46/EC) and the French data protection law (Law n°78-17 on 115 06/01/1978 and Décret n°2019-536 on 29/05/2019). Informed consent concerning the 116 disclosure of information relevant to this publication was obtained from the confirmed cases 117 in France. 118 Acknowledgements 119We would like to thank all the patients, clinicians, laboratory technicians and informatics 120 department who contributed to this investigation. We are also grateful to Véréna Landel and 121Philip Robinson (DRCI, Hospices Civils de Lyon) for help in manuscript preparation. We 122 thank the Authors, the Originating and Submitting Laboratories for their sequence and 123 metadata shared through GISAID on which this research is based.
